@lbendig, thanks for the efforts! I am wondering why you want to force guava version 15.0? Actually, it is safe to use the latest version 18.0 in Gobblin.

@liyinan926 The build.gradle defines Guava 15.0 as external dependency but if that version was not forced, a newer one was pulled during the build (17.0) which caused issues with other Hadoop versions (see HADOOP-10961).

LGTM! It looks ready to be merged.

One comment I had that can be addressed in another JIRA, is that I don't think we need to force the user to specify "--workdir" or $GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR in order for the script to run. Rather in the gobblin-mapreduce.properties file the user should set GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR.

The reason is that the launch scripts should only take in parameters that are needed to launch the job. The properties needed to run the job should be in the ".properties" file. The GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR is not needed to setup and launch the job, but only needed during runtime. Thus, I think it makes more sense to put GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR in the ".properties" file.

The layout of the .properties can be simple:

gobblin.work.dir=working/
writer.staging.dir=${gobblin.work.dir}/task-staging
etc.

@liyinan926 thoughts?

I agree that this can be addressed in a separate pull request. But I think the default value of `gobblin.work.dir` should not be hard-coded. Instead, it should always use `${env:GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR}` and we should set `GOBBLIN_WORK_DIR` to a default in the launch script, say, `working/` if it is not set.
Thanks a lot @lbendig for contributing! Merging it now.

@liyinan926 , @narasimhareddyv Thank you for reviewing and committing it!
We need to make access to S3 optionally via a proxy? That's how we deploy on internal hadoop cluster.

I think this can be done by configuring jets3t properties (which Hadoop S3 FS uses internally). Look for the various httpclient.proxy\* keys:

http://jets3t.s3.amazonaws.com/toolkit/configuration.html#jets3t

I'll research this and comment back.

If you add a file `conf/jets3t.properties` (relative to the Gobblin home directory) like below, Gobblin will use the specified proxy to connect to S3.

``` ini
httpclient.proxy-autodetect=false
httpclient.proxy-host=<host>
httpclient.proxy-port=<port>
```

Thanks for doing the research @rayortigas, this LGTM also. Based on the code and a little more research looks like connections to S3 from a Hadoop gateway can be done as follows:

1: Set the appropriate S3 environment variables that contain the credentials for connecting to S3
2: Add credentials to the core-site.xml file of the Hadoop cluster: https://wiki.apache.org/hadoop/AmazonS3

This pull request adds functionality to allow for option 1. If the env variables are present, they will be set in the Hadoop fs connection.

If there are no other comments, I can go ahead and do the Merge.

Hi @sahilTakiar,

The intent was to support option 1 but I think this will also cover option 2, in case the env vars are not set.

If I understand https://github.com/apache/hadoop/blob/trunk/hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/conf/Configuration.java#L678 correctly, the no-args `Configuration` constructor will pull default settings from `core-site.xml`.

Thanks,
Ray
I now realize that this is basically what you were saying, @sahilTakiar. :)
So, you basically had S3 support all along! :D Using env vars is probably more preferable, but the settings in `core-site.xml` would've worked fine.
Merged! Thanks for the contribution and investigation @rayortigas!
Updated.
How difficult is it to keep the task states, but remove the task states from the job state? The reason being the OOM issue will still occur if we go with this approach.

It's pretty tricky to not include task states in a job state since it also affects the deserialization as deserialization still expects to see the task states. Yeah, it won't solve the OOM issue. But still it's good to not writing task states as it's purely duplicated work.

The `WorkUnitState` returned here is still shared among the `Fork`s, and each `Fork` is submitted to run immediately after it is created. So this may still lead to race conditions.

We have re-used the same code in Voldemort by externalizing it in a standalone project called Tehuti, which can be pulled from Maven Central. The code is hosted on GitHub at http://tehuti.io
